moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4
comment: This loses a pawn. Correct is continuing development with 4. Bg5.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2
comment:
Black misses his chance to get a very strong
position with 6. ... Qxd1+ 7. Kxd1 Bg4!. This threatens 8. ... fxg2 discovered
check, followed by 9. ... gxh1(Q). Notice that if white tried 7. cxb7, then 7.
... fxg2+ 8. Ke1 gxh1(Q) 9. bxa8(Q) Qxa8 would leave black up a lot of
material. The move black chooses just develops white's bishop.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7
comment:
Yes! The correct move. This passed pawn is very strong,
and should have decided the game.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2
comment: Good! Respond to threats by developing pieces. Best chances that way.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1
comment: Correct. If possible develop with attack, like this move does.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4
comment:
?? Loses a piece by force. Black's position
was difficult, he had to figure out a way to get rid of White's thorn in his
side at b7. Otherwise, he might as well resign right now.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2
comment:
Too passive. Much stronger is 17. c3 Bc5 18. Bc8, forcing
black to sacrifice his rook because of white's threat of b8(Q), and after
exchanges on c8, would leave white up a full rook!

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1
comment:
No. Now that most pieces are exchanged, the king is a
fighting piece -- the threat of mate is non-existent. White should try to
support his passed b-pawn with 20. Kc3.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3
comment:
This works, but 21. Bc8!
Kf8 22. Rd1 would leave black in a complete bind. Black would be helpless to
stop white's plan of advancing her queen-side pawns, and forcing a
breakthrough on b6.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1
comment:
? Not the best. Let's take a look here. What
are the key elements of this position? Elements of chess are king safety,
material imbalances, space, development, for example. In this case, the key
facts are: 1) White has an extra bishop, and 2) the passed, PROTECTED pawn on
b7. The b7 pawn has the most potential, and should have been preserved if at
all possible. In this case it was, by playing Bc6 instead. Then the plan of 23.
Rd1, Rd7, Rxc7, followed by Rc8 is winning outright.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3
comment:
Not the best. The general rule of thumb when up a piece is in endgame is:
Trade pieces, NOT pawns. Conversely, if someone is losing, they should trade
pawns, not pieces. Correct was to preserve white's b-pawn with 24. b3. The
text makes it more difficult for white to win.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1
comment:
Again, now that mate threats are minimal, aggressive use of the king
is called for. White should advance toward the center with Kd2.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8
comment:
?! Dubious. White's bishop
was already well placed on d5. More logical was to get white's king involved
in the action with Ke2.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1
comment: Unnecessarily passive. Ke2 is still best.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2
comment:
Actually, 37.
Rg7+ Kh5 38. Kf3 would win material for white, plus bottle up black's king. A
mating net might even be possible. Otherwise, black's only choice would be 37.
... Kf6, but that loses the h6 pawn to Rg6+. That would present problems for
black since that would create a passed pawn (a passed pawn means unopposed by
enemy pawns).

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3
comment: There was a free pawn on c4. There was no reason not to take it.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4
comment:
Actually 48. Rf5+ Kh6 (...Kg6? 49. Rf1+ picks up black's
rook) Be2 would pick up black's last pawn, and probably make black resign.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+
comment:
Never give check just to give check! Only do it for a
good reason. Correct is 50. c4 (passed pawns must be pushed!) The black king
cannot get at white's rook, and can't win the bishop on e4 since white can
always preserve her bishop with Bd5, which also protects her rook on e6.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+ Kf4 51. Rxh5 Rxe4
comment:
Black makes an inaccuracy here. Now white can win by force. ...
Kxe4 would give black some chances to draw.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+ Kf4 51. Rxh5 Rxe4 52. Rh4+ Ke5 53. c3
comment:
Simply exchan
ging rooks followed by Kg4 would win easily for white. Black could have played
...Rd3+ leaving white only a pawn up.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+ Kf4 51. Rxh5 Rxe4 52. Rh4+ Ke5 53. c3 Rxh4+ 54. Kxh4 Kd5 55. Kg3
comment:
This works,
but generally this is the wrong move. In king and pawn endgames, the rule of
thumb is: Advance the king as much as is possible to support a pawn advance,
without jeopardizing the pawn's safety. Therefore, 55. Kg5 was the correct
move. If white's c-pawn were gone, black could draw by running his king to h8,
and white would unable to make progress. With Kg5, however, white can get to
g7 first, blocking black's king, and forcing white's h-pawn to queen.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+ Kf4 51. Rxh5 Rxe4 52. Rh4+ Ke5 53. c3 Rxh4+ 54. Kxh4 Kd5 55. Kg3 Kc4 56. h4 Kxc3 57. h5 Kd4 58. h6 Ke5 59. h7 Kf6 60. h8=Q+ Kg6 61. Kh4 Kf7 62. Qe5 Kg6 63. Qe8+ Kg7 64. Kg5 Kh7 65. Qg6+
comment:
Inaccurate. 65. Qe7+ Kh8 66. Kg6 Kg8 67.
Qg7#. When checkmating a lone king with a queen + king, you always want to
leave a legal move for the enemy king until it's checkmate. If you don't, then
black can escape with a draw by stalemate, which is exactly what happened in
this game.

moves: 1. Nf3 Nf6 2. Nc3 Nc6 3. d4 d5 4. e4 dxe4 5. d5 exf3 6. dxc6 fxg2 7. Bxg2 Qxd1+ 8. Kxd1 Bf5 9. cxb7 Rd8+ 10. Bd2 e5 11. Re1 Bd6 12. Bc6+ Bd7 13. Bf3 O-O 14. Ne4 Bg4 15. Nxf6+ gxf6 16. Bxg4 Bb4 17. Re2 Bxd2 18. Rxd2 Rxd2+ 19. Kxd2 Rd8+ 20. Ke1 Rb8 21. Bf3 f5 22. Rd1 e4 23. Bg2 Rxb7 24. f3 exf3 25. Bxf3 Rxb2 26. Rd8+ Kg7 27. Kd1 Rxa2 28. Bd5 Ra3 29. Rd7 c5 30. Rxf7+ Kg6 31. Rc7 Ra5 32. Bg8 h6 33. Bh7+ Kg5 34. Rf7 f4 35. Ke1 c4 36. Kf2 a6 37. Kg2 Kh4 38. Rxf4+ Kg5 39. Kg3 Ra2 40. Rg4+ Kf6 41. Rxc4 Ra3+ 42. Bd3 h5 43. Kh4 Ra1 44. Rc6+ Ke5 45. Rxa6 Rh1 46. Kh3 Kf4 47. Rf6+ Kg5 48. Be4 Re1 49. Re6 Re2 50. Re5+ Kf4 51. Rxh5 Rxe4 52. Rh4+ Ke5 53. c3 Rxh4+ 54. Kxh4 Kd5 55. Kg3 Kc4 56. h4 Kxc3 57. h5 Kd4 58. h6 Ke5 59. h7 Kf6 60. h8=Q+ Kg6 61. Kh4 Kf7 62. Qe5 Kg6 63. Qe8+ Kg7 64. Kg5 Kh7 65. Qg6+ Kh8 66. Kh6
comment:
So in conclusion, watch out for your opponent's
threats, and if you have passed pawns on the 7th rank (row), do all you can to
protect them. They can often decide games if they can queen, because they will
force more valuable pieces to sac themselves to stop it. Also, in endgames,
use your king to support your passed pawns, and to limit the activity of your
opponent's king.
